pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.html:
It seems that there are two ways of getting information about a model plugin: asking the world or asking the model. In both cases, the URI is the same. E.g.:

  • Using the model:
pluginUri.Parse(
     "data://world/default/model/submarine/plugin/submarine_propeller_3");
model->PluginInfo(pluginUri, plugins, success);
  • Using the world:
pluginUri.Parse(
  "data://world/default/model/submarine/plugin/submarine_propeller_3");
world->PluginInfo(pluginUri, plugins, success);

It looks a bit cleaner to me and probably easier to maintain if the Model class is the only option when asking for a model plugin. In a similar way, the World class should be the only option when asking for a world plugin.

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw:
The idea was for the world to be the only one to provide a service, and the request is forwarded to the relevant model from there. The world is not directly handling the request for model plugins, just forwarding the request to the relevant model.

Are you suggesting we have one service per model? And in the future, one service per sensor, etc? We could quickly end up with a huge list of services, which I thought was something we were trying to avoid.
content.html:
The idea was for the world to be the only one to provide a service, and the request is forwarded to the relevant model from there. The world is not directly handling the request for model plugins, just forwarding the request to the relevant model.

Are you suggesting we have one service per model? And in the future, one service per sensor, etc? We could quickly end up with a huge list of services, which I thought was something we were trying to avoid.

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw:
I see, I agree that it makes sense to do a single entry point for the service. My comment was more related with the `PluginInfo()` function, not the service callback. The `PluginInfo()` function in `World` handles all plugin types. One alternative would be to process the type of the request (model/world plugin) inside `pluginInfoService()`, and then, only call `model->PluginInfo()` or `this->PluginInfo()`. To summarize, we could move part of the logic that parses the request to `PluginInfoService()` and restrict `World::PluginInfo()` to only return information about world plugins.

In any case, this suggestion is totally optional. If you feel it's better as it is I'm totally OK with that. Just something to think about it.
content.html:
I see, I agree that it makes sense to do a single entry point for the service. My comment was more related with the PluginInfo() function, not the service callback. The PluginInfo() function in World handles all plugin types. One alternative would be to process the type of the request (model/world plugin) inside pluginInfoService(), and then, only call model->PluginInfo() or this->PluginInfo(). To summarize, we could move part of the logic that parses the request to PluginInfoService() and restrict World::PluginInfo() to only return information about world plugins.

In any case, this suggestion is totally optional. If you feel it's better as it is I'm totally OK with that. Just something to think about it.

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service
Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw:
Done dfc1fbe

Also changed the service to be `/physics/info/plugin`, so we can create other services for each library:

~~~
/sensors/info/plugin
/rendering/info/plugin
/gui/info/plugin
~~~

Come to think of it, we could even change it to be a more general `/<library>/info` service, which also returns entity info, for example. Then we deprecate the gazebo request which provides that currently. Thoughts?
content.html:
Done dfc1fbe

Also changed the service to be /physics/info/plugin, so we can create other services for each library:

/sensors/info/plugin
/rendering/info/plugin
/gui/info/plugin

Come to think of it, we could even change it to be a more general /<library>/info service, which also returns entity info, for example. Then we deprecate the gazebo request which provides that currently. Thoughts?

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw: So... These functions use `GetModel`, which is not const. And `GetModel` calls a bunch of other functions which are not const either. I've ran into this before and ended up with a non-const function because this requires too many changes. But I think these are necessary changes. So I propose we continue with this PR like this, and after I'll make a new PR just with all the necessary const changes. Sounds good?
content.html: So... These functions use GetModel, which is not const. And GetModel calls a bunch of other functions which are not const either. I've ran into this before and ended up with a non-const function because this requires too many changes. But I think these are necessary changes. So I propose we continue with this PR like this, and after I'll make a new PR just with all the necessary const changes. Sounds good?

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw:
About the warning, did you try modifying the Ignition Msg block in `SearchForStuff.cmake` and removing the `include_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_INCLUDE_DIRS})` from the main CMakeLists.txt? I don't even know why this is a warning and not an error if the compiler cannot find a header file. Just one thing to try at least.

```
#!c++

find_package(ignition-msgs0 0.4 QUIET)
if (NOT ignition-msgs0_FOUND)
  message(STATUS "Looking for ignition-msgs0-config.cmake - not found")
  BUILD_ERROR ("Missing: Ignition msgs0 library.")
else()
  message(STATUS "Looking for ignition-msgs0-config.cmake - found")
  include_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_INCLUDE_DIRS})
  link_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_LIBRARY_DIRS})
endif()
```
content.html:
About the warning, did you try modifying the Ignition Msg block in SearchForStuff.cmake and removing the include_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_INCLUDE_DIRS}) from the main CMakeLists.txt? I don't even know why this is a warning and not an error if the compiler cannot find a header file. Just one thing to try at least.

find_package(ignition-msgs0 0.4 QUIET)
if (NOT ignition-msgs0_FOUND)
  message(STATUS "Looking for ignition-msgs0-config.cmake - not found")
  BUILD_ERROR ("Missing: Ignition msgs0 library.")
else()
  message(STATUS "Looking for ignition-msgs0-config.cmake - found")
  include_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_INCLUDE_DIRS})
  link_directories(${IGNITION-MSGS_LIBRARY_DIRS})
endif()

content.raw: I think we could add some functionality to the URI class here (lines 1672->1689). You could add a `Compare` function to `URI` that operates in a manner similar to [std::string::compare](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/string/string/compare/).
content.html: I think we could add some functionality to the URI class here (lines 1672->1689). You could add a Compare function to URI that operates in a manner similar to std::string::compare.

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw: I feel like `std::string::compare` is more suitable when sorting. For this use case, we need something closer to `std::string::find`. Check out commit c3d8fbe, I implemented `URIPath::Contains`, which behaves like `std::string::find(_other) == 0`.
content.html: I feel like std::string::compare is more suitable when sorting. For this use case, we need something closer to std::string::find. Check out commit c3d8fbe, I implemented URIPath::Contains, which behaves like std::string::find(_other) == 0.

I'm returning true only if the result is zero though, because we are only interested if it matches from the beginning. This is written in the documentation, but I realize the function name might be misleading...

content.raw: I just ran a world with a model plugin and everything seems to work. I can click on the model and I see the plugin with the `name`, `filename` and `innerxml` properties. However, the `innerxml` property is hard to see/use because the content can be arbitrary big and is hard to see it on the widget. My first instinct is to remove it from the GUI unless someone has a more creative idea to visualize it.
content.html: I just ran a world with a model plugin and everything seems to work. I can click on the model and I see the plugin with the name, filename and innerxml properties. However, the innerxml property is hard to see/use because the content can be arbitrary big and is hard to see it on the widget. My first instinct is to remove it from the GUI unless someone has a more creative idea to visualize it.

pullrequest.title: Get plugin info with Ignition transport service

content.raw: This is a known issue. We decided to hold on any custom solutions for it for now because we will soon (hopefully) be changing the design of the left panel completely. I see what you're saying about removing it from the GUI, but as ugly as it may look, it can be helpful to check parameters, especially if it's short. I don't feel too strongly about it though, we can leave it out for now.
content.html: This is a known issue. We decided to hold on any custom solutions for it for now because we will soon (hopefully) be changing the design of the left panel completely. I see what you're saying about removing it from the GUI, but as ugly as it may look, it can be helpful to check parameters, especially if it's short. I don't feel too strongly about it though, we can leave it out for now.
